musicalLanguage.description: The 'Father of the Blues' wrote this in 1914, and it became one of the most recorded songs in history. The first section uses a habanera/tango rhythm that distinguishes it from standard 12-bar blues. The melody mixes blues notes with a sophisticated, almost orchestral sensibility.
musicalLanguage.structure: 12-bar blues form. This excerpt: 8 bars of the opening section
keyMoments: Bar 1-2: The habanera-flavored opening — NOT a standard shuffle. Feel the dotted rhythm.
Bar 3-4: G7 with blue notes — the melody bends between major and minor thirds
Bar 5-6: C7 (IV chord) — the harmony opens up while the habanera continues
Bar 7-8: Return to G7 with a classic blues turnaround feel
teachingGoals: Habanera rhythm — dotted-quarter + eighth + two quarters
Blue notes — the ambiguity between major and minor 3rd (B vs Bb)
Historical blues form — understanding the roots of American music
styleTips: The habanera feel is the key — do not play this as a straight shuffle
Blue notes should be slightly hesitant, not clean — they live between the cracks
Left hand is steady and rhythmic — it anchors the exotic rhythm

measures.teachingNote: G7 — the dotted rhythm gives the habanera feel. Bb is the blue note — let it growl.
G7 — the melody slides from Bb to B natural. That major/minor ambiguity IS the blues.
G7 continues. The melody repeats its signature dotted figure.
D7 — moving to the V chord briefly. F#4 is the major 3rd of D7.
C7 — the IV chord. Same melodic contour transposed up. Eb is the blue note over C.
C7 continues. The chromatic slide Eb-E is pure blues expression.
Back to G7 — the opening riff returns. Familiarity feels good.
D7 turnaround. The melody leaps down to F#4, setting up the repeat.
